PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. C.E. Diggle (Mrs. Carl E.)

Address: 1011 Dufferin Ave., Saskatoon

Birthplace: Prince Albert, Sask.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1879

   Where did you set up housekeeping? Collegeton, S. Alberta, Canada

   How far was it to your nearest store? 6 miles

   How often would a visit be made to the store? Twice a week

   What groceries did you usually buy in those early years? Groceries from the mill, white sugar, occasionally raisins, rolled oats, salted codfish, currant, dried apples, bread (not baked) and mixed curdles

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Hardman Bay

   How much did you buy at a time? 50 pounds

   In what quantities did you buy it? 50 pounds

   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.25

   How much did you use graham flour? 5 pounds

   Whole wheat flour locally? Yes

   Was flour milled locally? Yes

   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 35 cents

   What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, lactose, whole wheat flour

   Other? None

   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No

   How did you grind it? By hand

1. Diggle, Lottie Clarke (Mrs. Carl E).

**5.**

- **Carrots:** It appeared on the market in 1898.
- **Canned salmon**
- **Canned corned beef**
- **Other canned fish that spoiled early**
- **Grapes**
- **Apples - fresh**
- **Lettuce**
- **Tomatoes - fresh**
- **Bananas - occasionally to be had in quantities**
- **Oranges to be bought from early days on but very scarce**
- **Cornflakes**
- **Other prepared breakfast cereals - give**
- **Pearl tapioca**
- **Instant tapioca**
- **Sago**
- **Dates**
- **Peanuts - brought in shell from as early as 1887**
- **Ice cream sugar was new until about 1904.**

---

**12. WATER SUPPLY**

There did you not water for drinking and for cooking? (roll, river, spring, dugout)

If so, where was this water for your home? (roll, barrel, tank, reservoir, from spring, from well)

How was it brought to the house (roll, barrel, tank, reservoir) from where?

Has earlier water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If so, did you use it?

What kind of laundry soap did you use?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days?

There did you get your fuel?

Describe any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days?

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made?

That year was it purchased?

Price?

Types of utensils did you use?

For preserving food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

Then did you first see metal ware?

Aluminum...
13. CARE

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?

If you did, what kind was used?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in an earthen stove?

There did you get your fuel?

Did you have any changes in the use of fuel which have taken place since you first started housekeeping?

15. HEATING & COOKING APPLIANCE

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days?

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By show us your first cook stove made?

That year was it purchased? (Give date)

What type of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homestead)

For outdoor cooking, how did you do it?

Then did you first see smoke from aluminum?
16. **TRADITIONS AND CUSTOMS**

Imagine any changes which you recall in the arrangements and combinations received with the food you purchased (give dates here if possible).

---

17. Give a typical day's meal (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at that time.

**Breakfast - fried potatoes, fried pork, fried white bread, butter.**

**Dinner - roast duck or turkey with potatoes, corn, fried carrots.**

**Supper - baked pudding with raisins, eaten with cream.**

---

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in lanterns? How many candles did you use?

---

19. Here you overwintered foods? Olive details. What nine months years? Describe the conditions. How hard was it to be brought with them and what we raised. I can remember being without food for many days.

---

24. How do you feel about the occasion? Please tell all kinds and even aged nuts grown at W.C.

---

Hence don't think we ever suffered from definite malnutrition. Indeed, purchased plenty.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the winter.

18. Thank you all for your Christmas dinner in Eastern Tennessee.

19. For you who have been living on one or two farms and dairies, they were my goal for anything we raised. I love hard to be brought with cows and I can remember every animal raised for many years.

24 hours on two different occasions. Besides I am proud and ever eager nuts grown at V.C.

Hence I don't think we can afford more definitely. (signature)

Plants.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give us early details and dates and possible reasons.)

When you property came about 1900

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods in their raw form, earlier pioneer days in Western Canada.

Potatoes and vegetables were stored in a dirt cellar and sometimes were forced-pasteurized. They were stored in crocks, old pitchpots, earthenware, handle, whiskey bottles with the necks cut off by tying a string dipped in creosol. Often there were only 3 stencils for cooking on top of stove, oven or pot that held 8 quarts, an iron pan that held 2 quarts and a drying pan. There was also a baby's favorite corner was covered with brown paper to hold juices. Both was set in open tin pans and the corner was trimmed off.
21. When did you begin to roll out prepared foods and preserves? (Give an early date, 1875 and dates in parenthesis.)

22. Potato and vegetables were stored in a diet cellar and sometimes were buried in the ground. Old pickle bottles with the necks cut off were stored in creels, old pitchpots, or crocks. Often there were only 3 utensils for cooking on top of a stove, a pot that held guests, an empty pot that held gravy and a frying pan. There was also a baby's favorite vessel, a covered tin pan with brown paper in holding juices.

Paula was not in town then and the children were not allowed to go out at night.
